abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts, and,
            similarly, ratings assess the Bank performance as
            satisfactory, and that of the Borrower as highly
            satisfactory. Lessons of success are attributed, first, to a
            consistent political will, government commitment, and strong
            ownership, irrespective of administration changes. Likewise,
            the participatory approach, and consultation process helped
            dilute social risks, during project preparation,
            negotiations, and implementation, especially with trade
            unions, and, in particular, the Master Plan Study
            participatory management, and appropriate Project Steering
            Committee complemented the nature of this project. The
            project is thus looked upon as a role model in the
            implementation of projects in Mauritius, a project which was
            instrumental in creating a new vision for port management,
            as well as for social aspects with the introduction of the
            Voluntary Retirement Scheme concept. Regardless of success,
            the exchange risk issue, faced by the Mauritius Ports
            Authority (MPA), exposed the limitations of the existing
            financial market arrangements, to a large extent, beyond
            MPA's control. This suggests the Government should
            consider other financial instruments, to provide
            institutional ability to hedge against foreign exchange
            risks; similarly, the Bank should consider introducing some
            mechanisms/formula to limit client's exposure on
            foreign exchange as a percentage of its revenue.
